title: 111_s591
content:
The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission for the purposes of addressing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel. The commission's composition, duties, powers, staff, compensation, and termination are outlined in the Act. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission to evaluate potential improvements in the management of radioactive waste and submit a report to Congress with recommendations. The Commission shall consist of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with appropriate committees. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by different leaders in consultation with appropriate committees. Qualifications for appointees include restrictions on involvement in high-level radioactive waste activities and government affiliations. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed based on qualifications that include restrictions on involvement in high-level radioactive waste activities and government affiliations. Members should be prominent US citizens with expertise in various fields relevant to nuclear fuel management. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed based on qualifications that include restrictions on involvement in high-level radioactive waste activities and government affiliations. Members should be prominent US citizens with expertise in engineering, science, energy, governmental service, environmental policy, law, public administration, or foreign affairs. The deadline for appointment is 90 days after the enactment of the Act, with the Chairperson appointed under subsection (a)(5) serving as the Commission's leader. The Commission will begin operations promptly after the Act's enactment and will meet as needed after the initial meeting. The Commission, consisting of 9 members with specific qualifications, will start operations promptly after the Act's enactment. Meetings will be called by the Chairperson or majority members, with a quorum of five members required. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation, providing necessary authority and funding for storage and management, and exploring cost-sharing options. The Federal Government corporation is tasked with providing authority and funding for storage and management of high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel. Cost-sharing options with private industry, centralized interim storage facilities, and research on advanced fuel cycle technologies are also key components. Research and development for advanced fuel cycle technologies, transferring title of spent nuclear fuel inventories to the Department of Energy, and requiring transfer of spent nuclear fuel inventories to at-reactor dry casks. Future nuclear fuel inventories at reactor sites need to be managed for public safety and security, including transferring spent nuclear fuel to at-reactor dry casks after 7 years in a cooling pond. Long-term solutions for spent nuclear fuel management involve permanent deep geologic disposal for civilian and defense wastes, along with interim strategies for treating defense wastes. Additional management and technological advancements are also necessary. The Commission will consult with various stakeholders to make recommendations on the disposition of nuclear fuel inventories, including long-term solutions for permanent deep geologic disposal and interim strategies for treating defense wastes. Additional management and technological approaches will also be considered. The Commission, in consultation with stakeholders, will submit recommendations on the disposition of nuclear fuel inventories, including long-term deep geologic disposal and interim strategies for defense wastes. They will also analyze the financial impacts of these recommendations on the Federal Government's contractual liability under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982. The Commission will analyze the financial impacts of their recommendations on the Federal Government's contractual liability under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 and submit a final report to Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and enter into contracts to carry out its duties. It can also obtain information from federal agencies for the purposes of this Act. The Commission has the authority to obtain information from federal agencies as needed for the Act's purposes. This information must be provided in a timely manner upon request by the Chairperson or designated member, and can only be handled by Commission members and staff. The Commission can request timely statistics from federal agencies, which must be handled in accordance with applicable laws. The General Services Administration provides administrative support to the Commission, and other departments and agencies may also offer assistance. The General Services Administration provides administrative support to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Other federal departments and agencies can also offer services, funds, facilities, staff, and support as requested and authorized by law. The Commission is allowed to use the United States mails like other government entities. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission, and staff is also addressed. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint staff without following certain federal employment rules, with a salary limit. Staff members are considered federal employees. The Commission's staff director and employees are federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Members of the Commission are not considered federal employees. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their rights and status. Members of the Commission are exempt from certain regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their rights and privileges. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants at specified rates. SEC. 9. Compensation for Commission members includes daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Travel expenses are covered while on Commission business. SEC. 10. Commission members are eligible for security clearances. SEC. 10. Security clearances are provided to Commission members and staff by Federal agencies to access classified information. SEC. 11. REPORTS.

The Commission must release an interim report within 1 year for public comment, and a final report to Congress within 2 years. The final report includes agreed findings, dissenting opinions with explanations, and considers public comments. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Act, with funds available until expended. The Commission's authority terminates 180 days after the final report submission, during which it can conclude its activities and disseminate the final report.
